title: Bank of Ireland branch set for closure
story: BANK of Ireland has been asked to reconsider its decision to close its Downpatrick branch as part of a major cost cutting programme.The Market Street branch is one of  across Northern Ireland which has been earmarked for closure, a move which local politicians have warned will have an impact on jobs, the economy and customers.Bank officials have confirmed that they are working to identy staff who could be redeployed to other roles within the company as an alternative to redundancy and that branch closures will not start for  weeks.Customers will be contacted inidually about the changes which comes as Bank of Ireland signicantly restructures its Northern Ireland business which includes simplying its range of products with a greater focus on car finance and mortgages.There has been widespread political criticism of the decision to close the Downpatrick branch which has been led by South Down MP Chris Hazzard.A number of MLAs have voiced concern while there was unanimous support for an emergency motion tabled at Monday nightrsquos meeting of Newry, Mourne and Down Council urging Bank of Ireland to retain the Downpatrick branch. A council delegation is also seeking a meeting with bank officials.Mr Hazzard described the proposed closure in the teeth of a global pandemic as ldquothe wrong decision at the worst possible time, with serious consequences for local customers and staff.He said: ldquoBank of Ireland has attempted to justy this announcement based on a fall in branch visits over the past  months. This is hardly surprising given the entire population has had its movements signicantly restricted inresponse to a public health emergency.ldquoIn reality, the bank is using Covid- for cover, punishing customers for following public health regulations. This is not just a cynical move, but a slap in the face that will hurt customers, staff and communities. This knee-jerk reaction will leave vulnerable customers without access to essential services.The MP said Sinn Fein supported the call from the Financial Services Union for a moratorium on branch closures until the end of , once the pandemic has ended.South Down MLA Colin McGrath said the Bank of Ireland has been a ldquopillar in the financial institutions of Downpatrick for a generation.ldquoIt is a sad facet of modern le that banking is no longer a face-to-face task like it once was, he continued. ldquoLarger banks are having to adjust their business models as a result of this but it is taking away from our high streets and that is sad.He confirmed that the SDLP Assembly team is liaising with Bank of Ireland to ensure that there is minimal disruption to customers and ldquocredible alternatives in place for those that wish to stay with the bank.Jim Wells MLA said South Down had lost half of its bank branches in the past  years, warning thatthe present trend continues, the constituency will be a ldquobank free zone within the next decade.He said the decision to shut the Downpatrick branch was not a shock as Bank of Ireland had already closed branches in Kilkeel and Rathfriland, describing the trend as ldquo extremely worrying.Downpatrick councillors Oonagh Hanlon, Gareth Sharvin, Dermot Curran and John Trainor have also criticised the planned closure of the Downpatrick branch.Cllr Hanlon accused Bank of Ireland of making a ldquoknee-jerk reaction that cannot be justied with many local businesses and families in Downpatrick left in a very vulnerable position because of this ldquocruel decision. She has urged the bank to reverse its closure decision immediately and commit to a moratorium on closures until the pandemic ends.Cllr Sharvin mdash who proposed the emergency motion at Monday nightrsquos council meeting mdash called on bank officials to urgently clary how they will support customers and workers.ldquoThis move will undoubtedly leave vulnerable and elderly customers without access to essential services. It is also highly disappointing that there appears to have been very little local consultation or stakeholder engagement on this decision, he added.Cllr Trainor said that over recent years there has been a migration of business away from city and town centres to the internet, followed by the collapse of trade in traditional retail centres as a result of the Covid pandemic.Cllr Curran said he was concerned that Bank of Irelandrsquos move leaves Downpatrick with just three banks which will impact on customers and the business community..prettyPhoto

title: Clampdown on visitors
story: POLICE are being urged to clampdown on all non-essential travel across the district after tourist attractions and beauty spots were swamped with thousands of visitors last weekend.Despite the continued circulation of the deadly coronavirus, people made the most of the warm weather, swarming to Newcastle, Murlough, Tollymore and Castlewellan forest parks, Delamont Country Park outside Killyleagh, the Quoile River in Downpatrick and beaches and villages dotted along the Lecale coastline.One image of a packed Newcastle Main Street last Sunday posted on social media has shocked local politicians who say people need to continue to exercise social distancing as the virus has not gone away.Mournes councillors Laura Devlin and Willie Clarke have expressed concern about the huge increase in visitors to the district, many of whom are not adhering to public health advice.They insist that there is no room for complacency at this crucial time and have warned that failure to comply with public health advice places others at risk, despite the decrease in new coronavirus cases locally and continued roll out of a comprehensive vaccination programme.Cllr Devlin confirmed that she is so concerned at what happened that she has urged police to deploy additional resources to the Newcastle area in particular, admitting that this would be a ldquodrastic measure to enforce the public health message.She has warned that what happened last Sunday at popular beauty spots and destinations across the district has the potential to destroy local efforts over the winter months to curtail the virus.ldquoThe scenes in Newcastle last weekend had to be seen to be believed, she declared.ldquoWe remain in lockdown and people should only be out and aboutitrsquos deemed essential, or for specic reasons.ldquoI wrote to the First and Deputy First Ministers in the New Year asking that a travel restrictions be implemented, but the  mile from home limit is advisory, not enforceable.ldquoWe are all entitled to our exercise and fresh air and itrsquos vital that we avail of it butwe arrive somewhere and itrsquos too busy, the onus is on us to go somewhere . I have total sympathy for those living right in the thick of this as for many they are prisoners in their own homes.Cllr Devlin confirmed that she has spoken with police asking for additional officers to be deployed to Newcastle, pointing to the need for checkpoints along busy routes.ldquoI think that that the extra visibility of police would make a dference. Whilst this sounds drastic, the scenes from last Sunday have the potential to destroy much of our local efforts over the winter.ldquoWe are hopeful to be near the end of this lockdown and want it to be our last. However, last weekendrsquos scenes are deeply worrying. We know the beauty of our area and depend upon tourism, but not now. Now is not the time.Cllr Devlin said she fears that with the weather improving, the current situation is going to get worse, but hopes that as the vaccination programme continues to roll out, people will feel that bit more secure and safe in their locality.ldquoI would encourage everyone to avail of the opportunity to have the vaccine to protect themselves and others in the community to help us all to get to a better place. It is also important to continue adhering to public health advice, she said.Cllr Clarke raised his concerns about the huge influx of visitors with senior Newry, Mourne and Down Council officials, pointing to recent problems in Newcastle and surrounding areas, including the Bloody Bridge, Murlough beach, Keel Point and Tollymore forest park.ldquoIn recent weeks we have seen a signicant rise in visitors to Newcastle and the growing concern of the community is that many people are too relaxed when it comes to adhering to guidelines on social distancing and face masks, he said.ldquoI have emphasised that there needs to be better co-ordination between police, local council and the Department for Infrastructure. The provision of cones helped deter illegal parking last weekend at the Trassey Road and Bloody Bridge but some of the cones were removed by police. The cones need to be provided all year round.Cllr Clarke confirmed that he has asked the council chief executive, Mrs Marie Ward, to ensure that police are stopping all non-essential travel and are monitoring the districtrsquos tourism hotspots.He added: ldquoI am working with a local landowner at the Bloody Bridge and the local council to potentially provide additional car parking spaces at this popular attraction.ldquoThe lack of compliance to health advice not only puts others at risk, but frontline hospitality staff, retail workers and the community.ldquoLocal residents have made major sacrices to reduce the spread of Covid  across the community and we need to ensure visitors exercise social distancing, wash their hands and wear masks while visiting for essential travel..prettyPhoto

title: Daisy Lodge helping families during Covid
story: FOR families living with cancer or mourning the loss of a loved one to the disease, the fact that Daisy Lodge is running at half its normal capacity still makes it a sanctuary ndash especially through the pandemic.Run by the Cancer Fund for Children, the centre on Newcastlersquos Bryansford Road provides short therapeutic breaks for families.The chance of getting a whf of sea air, a walk along the beach and a view of the stunning Mournes is something that all families appreciate. When itrsquos combined with the care and attention that Daisy Lodge gives to them, it means a rare spell of respite in whatrsquos a truly challenging period in their lives.Normally welcoming just over  families through its doors each year, Daisy Lodge resumed breaks last July after having to suspend breaks from mid-March last year due to the spread of Covid-.Resident Services Manager Raphael OrsquoConnor says that while the centre has had a reduced capacity, his staff of  have ensured that familiesrsquo experience are more intensely therapeutic for each short break.He knows that the  families who have been stayed at Daisy Lodge since last summer have really needed and appreciated the break.ldquoWe are dealing with extremely vulnerable client group, children and parents with cancer. Because of their cancer treatment have extremely low immunity, they would be viewed as high risk during normal times, said Raphael, who is a nurse by profession.ldquoWith the Covid- situation, families have felt extremely vulnerable and having a short break here has been a lesaver for a lot of families.He said that the decision to close last March was ldquogutting to him and his staff, but realised that it was based on current advice and policy.Staff were furloughed for four months, although online and digital support was offered to families and the charityrsquos community services team still worked with families in hospitals and at home.However, knowing how valued the breaks were to families, Raphael and his team did a major online consultation with the Department of Health, its board and families to assess the attitude to a re-opening. The response was that % of families were willing to take a short break at Daisy Lodge.ldquoWhat became clear was because of the high need our families were in at that time, getting the break was essential, particularly for families with someone in a palliative condition. While we are not a hospice, families needed somewhere to come to spend those last few weeks to be together, said Raphael.However, before they opened their doors to two families per week in July, Raphaelrsquos team had major work to do.He explained: ldquoWe had to redraft our entire Covid procedure for hygiene, PPE, the donning and doffing of these, temperature checks with a digital thermometer, etc.ldquoOur protocols had to be of a standard comparable to a hospital ward. Overnight we had to become very clinical, which is something we had moved away from as Daisy Lodge was to be an experience away from the hospital ward.One family memberrsquos feedback comment illustrates what the break meant to them.The Covid- pandemic has made navigating le with a cancer diagnosis extremely dficult. Our quality of le is already compromised and the fear of contracting the virus has forced us all into isolation, they said.ldquoDuring our stay in Daisy Lodge we felt confident that we could relax and be together knowing that everything was being done to ensure our comfort and safety. It felt like a refuge, a safe-haven.Raphael remarked: ldquoWe know we are making a huge dferent to the lives of these families and that despite Covid, they have been able to come here and enjoy themselves and forget about it.ldquoWe exist for families with cancer and kids with cancer, we wouldnrsquot be doing this workwe didnrsquot feel passionate about it.ldquoWe know the magic that this place gives families. They leave us walking on air, feeling rejuvenated, feeling that they can cope with whatrsquos ahead. We know we help them on their journey and the feeling that we couldnrsquot do that during the first lockdown, yes, we were all disappointed.The charity was funded by over pound, from the Executive in July in recognition of the role it provides and the impact that the lockdown had on its finances. It requires pound.m per year to provide its services to families across Northern Ireland.Raphael added: ldquoWe plan to continue to aim for this target despite the challenges of Covid- and the impact this has had on fundraising. We have confidence in our dedicated fundraising team but rely now more than ever on the support of the wider community across Northern Ireland.He says he is proud of his team who have risen to every challenge during the last year.ldquoI have a very resilient and diligent group of staff who they go above and beyond for families. Itrsquos the best team I have ever worked with and they deliver time and time again for families, despite all the new changes and new procedures. They retrained, they adapted quickly and our cleaning regime is now second to none.The remaining issue for Raphael is how to deal with the many families who still require a short break.ldquoWe are on the back foot going forward as we know we have a backlog of families needing breaks. When restrictions ease and we are back delivering five or six families a week, we are going to have a greater demand than ever.To find out how to donate to the charity, visit www.cancerfundforchildren donate..prettyPhoto

title: Eimear and Gavin nominated for prestigious volunteer accolade
story: TWO local GAA members are in the running for a major volunteering accolade.Eimear Murray, from Loughinisland, and Gavin OrsquoShea, from Ardglass, have been nominated for the Translinkrsquos Young GAA Volunteer of the Year Award.Seven other members of Down clubs have been dominated for the award, which celebrates the outstanding contribution made by young members of the GAA to their clubs and communities throughout the challenges of the Covid- pandemic.Eimear Murray was appointed secretary of Loughinisland GAC last November.In nominating Eimear for the award, the club said: ldquoIt is a huge responsibility and workload in a committee especially at such a young age. However, she has adapted to her new role brilliantly and with complete ease.Gavin helps out with the Ardglass senior squad and is ever present at matches and training sessions.The Ardglass club said: ldquoHe helps with collecting footballs, sorting out training equipment and water bottles, helping to clean the club rooms and grounds. He also keenly gets involved in helping out with any fundraisers.The competition is open to GAA members aged - and the aim is to find those whose actions best demonstrate the volunteering ethos and community spirit of the GAA.The winner will receive a certicate and specially-commissioned Volunteer of the Year merchandise from Ulster GAA. As well as that, courtesy of Translink, there will be a voucher for complimentary Enterprise Class travel for two people to Dublin.The winner also receives a free set of Translink-sponsored underage jerseys for their club..prettyPhoto

title: Family’s relief after parents recover from Covid
story: A BALLYNAHINCH couple who battled the deadly coronavirus in hospital are delighted to be back in their home safe and well.Ethne and Ronnie Douglas were reunited two weekends ago after being treated for the virus at the Ulster Hospital in Dundonald with the couplersquos family raising pound, to purchase new nursing unorm watches for the staff who had looked after them to say thank you.Married for  years, the local couple spent weeks fighting the virus after they became ill at the end of January.Mrs Douglasbecame ill on January  while her husband mdash who is  mdash became unwell a few days later.While the couple was initially looked after at home, their condition deteriorated in early February and they were taken to hospital by separate ambulances at what was a deeply worrying time for their family.Ethne and Ronnie were admitted to the hospital and placed in beds opposite one another. They were also placed on so-called CPAP machines which are specially designed to help people with their breathing by delivering oxygen air into the airways through a mask and tube.The couple then developed Covid pneumonia and on February  Mr Douglas, who has five daughters with his we, was admitted to the intensive care unit.One of the couplersquos daughters, Karen Watts, said the family felt ldquocompletely helpless at having both their parents in hospital fighting Covid-.ldquoIt is devastating because you think the worst and because they are older and you hear so many stories, she said.ldquoIt was the possibility of losing them both together. It was awful, even one. One would be completely lost without the other. I see that now.While in intensive care, Mr Douglasrsquos condition improved and a few days later he was readmitted to ward four at the Ulster mdash which treats coronavirus patients mdash to be near his we.However, her condition had deteriorated and the family believe that it was because she had ldquolost hope that her husband had been taken to ICU.Thankfully, within a few days of her husband ing to the ward, Mrs Douglasrsquos condition began to improve.On Saturday, February , Mr Douglas was discharged from hospital and ed to the couplersquos home in Ballynahinch to be followed eight days later by his we.Mrs Watts said she and her family was relieved and grateful to have them home and paid tribute to the staff at the Ulster Hospital who had cared for them.ldquoThey [the staff] are not just doing the basics, they are going above and beyond what they need to do. They are absolutely brilliant. Even the things dad tells us about what happened within the ward, she told the Irish News.Mrs Watts, a science teacher who also lives in Ballynahinch, said her family is so thankful to the staff that they raised pound, for them.When the staff were asked what they wanted the family to buy for them with the money, they requested new watches for their unorms and so  were purchased with the funds.ldquoIt was to say thank you for the work they were doing, she said.ldquoThey were going the extra mile for them and going the extra mile for us because they were keeping us informed on how they were doing and they donrsquot get enough recognition for what they are doing.The mother-of-two said her parentsrsquo recovery had been ldquoamazing and said it just shows how quickly things can swing either way.She continued: ldquoMum had lost hope when she heard dad had gone to ICU. Then he came back and the nurses remarked that she was like a new woman. They could see an improvement. The two of them perked up from that point.Mrs Watts said that it was a real a miracle that her parents both got through it Covid and did so quickly.She added: ldquoThey do genuinely spur each other along. Now they are at home together they will help each otherrsquos recovery because they have a long road in front of them. We have a lot to be thankful for, times two, for mum and dad..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C March 7%2C 2001
story: DOWNPATRICK ndash A Downpatrick man remains in intensive care in a Belfast hospital after being savagely beaten in a vicious weekend assault.The  year-old sustained severe head injuries, including a fractured skull, when he was beaten with what police have described as a metal ball and chain and an ornamental glass kne.The man and three friends were brutally attacked in the Irish Street area during the early hours of last Saturday morning in what has been described as an unprovoked violent attack. A senior police officer has said the motive for the attack may be sectarian.One of the injured men sustained a broken leg during the incident and had to be treated for his injury at the Downe Hospital in the town.At first light on Saturday, a blood-stained part of Irish Street was sealed off by police to allow a detailed search of the area to be carried out. Forensic scientists also combed the area where the assault had taken place in the search for clues.BALLYNAHINCH ndash Dozen more jobs are likely to go from a Ballynahinch firm which laid off  workers last week.Sources within telecommunications company, Viasystems, have this week revealed that  more employees now face the axe. The warning comes just days after all the temporary shop floor workers are released by the company.These employees were told they were no longer needed when they were summoned to a special meeting in the factory on Wednesday.Although management is refusing to comment on claims that more workers are now set to lose their jobs, staff on the permanent pay roll yesterday said they had been warned they may be next to go.Office and shop floor workers were asked to consider voluntary redundancy during an emergency meeting at the factory earlier this week in an effort to achieve the staff cuts.KILLYLEAGH ndash The final fate of Killyleagh High School may have been indirectly sealed by the Education Ministerrsquos recent announcement of the schoolsrsquo budget for .The campaign to reopen the Killyleagh school has been dealt a serious blow following the allocation of a multi-million pound new building grant to Comber High School.The Comber school was awarded poundm within this yearrsquos capital programme, following a -year campaign by the schoolrsquos Board of Governors.The construction of the new Comber school will mark a signicant first for local education because for the first time a private company will build and maintain the new complex. The Department of Education will then pay a ldquomortgagersquo over the next  years.But a source close to the Department has this week warned that the state-of-the-art structure destined for Comber makes it ldquoextremely unlikely Killyleagh High will ever reopen.ARDGLASS ndash A major new education facility in Ardglass opens for business today.The Ardglass Development Association is the driving force behind a new information technology initiative which is based in the villagersquos community centre and funded by the local group.Other key partners include the Rural Development Council, the National Lottery Charities Board and the International Fund for Ireland.The Downpatrick firm of ITA Computers has installed six computers in a specially designed suite and will pave the way for IT training classes to be conducted in the centre.Initial beginners classes, which are being organised in conjunction with the East Down Institute, are free of charge and are scheduled to commence today.DRUMANESS ndash One of the most familiar faces in Drumnaess has bid a fond farewell to the village after  years as the local postmaster.Mr Brian Quinn who, along with we Eileen, took the Mill Road premises over on March , , says deciding to leave his job has been a very hard thing to do.Over the years Brian and Eileen have served the local community, and it hasnrsquot just been selling stamps and sorting letters.As he explained, running Drumaness Post Office was not a normal nine to five job. From early morning Brian would be on the go, delivering groceries, coal and gas, sometimes not finishing until pm or pm at night.Brian says he will hold some very special memories of Drumaness and its residents, and has agreed to continue running the stow until its new owners take over in a few weeks time.CLOUGH ndash The Clough Community Association will soon be able to boast a new computer, thanks to British Telecom.The state-of-the-art facility is due to be installed within the next few days after the local community group impressed BT chiefs behind community connections initiative.The Clough group is one of  across the province to be recognised for its work with local people and the community and its officials are delighted a new computer is on the way.Mr John Knipe, the grouprsquos assistant secretary, said the computer will be used to help produce a local newsletter detailing forthcoming events and activities.NEWCASTLE ndash The Newcastle swimming pool under threat of closure has received a prestigious trophy for its contribution to lesaving.The Rock Pool is to receive the Royal Lesaving Societyrsquos Donaldson Cup, the premier trophy in Northern Ireland for council-owned swimming pools.Campaigners fighting for the retention of the  year-old amenity have said the prominent award highlights the important role the pool plays in the community.To win the award lesaving tutors and students at the pool had to amass more competition points than those at other pools in the Province. The award to the Rock Pool is all the more signicant because it is open for just two months a year and was competing against facilities which are open all year round.CROSSGAR ndash An award-winning Crossgar house, which was once a working mill, is to be featured on television next week.The home of Tom Woolley, Professor of Architecture at Queenrsquos University, and Rachel Bevan, a noted architect, will be featured on UTVrsquos interior design series, lsquoAbout the Housersquo, next Tuesday.The house, which is a conversion of an old ruined water mill, won architectural award from the Royal Society of Architects last year. It is an example of Eco-design in which as much of the existing structure was retained as possible. Most of the new materials were recycled and are free of toxic chemicals.ANNSBOROUGH ndash Irelandrsquos best loved show band legend will make on of his rare County Down appearances this Saturday night at Annsborough GAA social club.Brian Coll has been booked to perform the local gig which is expected to draw big crowds.He will be joined on the night by Banbridgersquos king of yodel, Reggie Gilliland, as well as Donegal singing star Sinead McGavigan.The fabulous lsquoCountry Harmonyrsquo will prove the music for what promises to be a night of top class entertainment.SPORT ndash Sport throughout Down District is facing another weekend wipe-out as a result of the foot and mouth crisis.All rugby, hockey and gaelic games fixtures booked have been cancelled for the second weekend running and soccer looks almost certain to follow suit.The IFA has delayed making a final decision until later today, but the signs are that it will order another shutdown across the province.Last night it was being suggested that a resumption will take place on March  at the earliest..prettyPhoto

title: Jim was pioneering engineer
story: A CROSSGAR man is hoping that a book will be written chronicling the le of a Ballynahinch businessman who featured in a recent novel written by his daughter.The Settlement mdash penned by writer Ruth Kirby-Smith mdash was inspired by her garage owner father Jim Brown whose business was based in Dromore Street.The book is based on a fictional Armagh village, but features a number of local locations including The Spa, the Mournes and a former rectory which is now the Millbrook Lodge Hotel.The novelist is also the sister of John and Junior Brown who are friends with Alan Lyons, well known in local motorsport circles.Alan, who is also one of the driving forces behind the campaign for new memorials in Killyleagh and Crossgar to mark the achievements of former road racer Brian Steenson who lost his le following a crash while competing at the Isle of Man TT in , is looking forward to reading the new novel as it covers a period in Ireland which for him is an ldquointriguing part of history that not much has been written about.Describing James Brown as a ldquoremarkable man, Mr Lyons said it would be fittinga book was written about him and the impact that he had on so many people. While friends with John and Junior, Alan said he was also proud to have known their father very well.ldquoTo say that Jim was an acknowledged engineering genius is no overstatement, he continued.ldquoJim told me that he served his apprenticeship at Stewartrsquos Motor Works in Downpatrick before World War Two and thought the world of James Stewart whom he referred to as lsquogolden handsrsquo because he could turn his hand to anything.ldquoJim then worked for the former Ulster Transport Authority during the war and opened his Antrim Road Garage in Ballynahinch in late  which he purchased with a loan from a family friend.Alan also revealed that Jim and his son John sponsored him when he used to race cars.He continued: ldquoOnce Jim, or JN as he was known, started to help me with mechanical development, I quickly moved from being a back marker to a front runner in no amount of time. Jim always said that % of winning was done in the workshop before the race meetings.ldquoJim was very much a self-made man with an independent pattern of thought and kept his motorcycling hobby quite separate from his business interests, Alan explained.ldquoWhile he preferred not to align himself with any dealership other than David Brown Tractors, for whom he did development work and sold numerous new and second-hand tractors, he steadfastly refused to repair road going motorcycles.Alan revealed that it was Jimrsquos love of motorcycles and an interest in tuning and modying British machines, a process later adopted by manufacturers like BSA, Norton and Triumph in the s that earned him a much-envied reputation.He said James was ldquoalways extremely modest about his dramatic successes as he was happy developing innovation after innovation in his own workshop.ldquoJim was certainly well ahead of his time when explaining in simple terms that engines had to be enabled to breathe easily to make them perform better, Alan explained.ldquoHis new thinking about breathing, valve and camshaft design, carbureation and compression ratios brought phenomenal output at , rpm from an ordinary production BSA machine when the company was the worldrsquos biggest motorcycle producers in the mid-s, long before the surge of Japanese two-strokes.Many years later, Alan said he still finds it hard to understand that Jim Brown was given motorcycles by leading manufacturers with an instruction to keep them winning at world class level, which is exactly what he did.He also revealed that a lot of Jimrsquos ideas were incorporated into the BSA cc Victor machine that Jeff Smith used to win the motocross world championship in  and .Alan revealed that in earlier years, Jim provided Irish champion road-racer Wilfie Herron with a race-bike, as he did for Ian McGregor, Campbell Gorman and Tom Herron.ldquoHailed as a wizard, he personally tailored the BSA bikes which brought Mervyn McConkey so much success on grass tracks and motocross events throughout Ireland, he continued.The Crossgar man said that when Jim lost interest in the motorcycle industry because of its domination by Japanese-built machines, he turned to Cosworth, who employed him as a consultant.ldquoJim became great friends with Keith Duckworth, the English mechanical engineer famous for designing the Cosworth double four valve cylinder engine and cylinder head, and was also great friends with Sir Frank Williams and Sir Patrick Head from the Williams Formula One team, said Alan.ldquoThrough my friendship with Jim and his we Minnie and their sons John and Junior, I met some wonderful people. Jim was great friends with the Rev Harold Good who latter became the Moderator of the Methodist Church in Ireland, while I helped the Brown family run motorsport events in the Martin and McCormickrsquos quarries in the eighties in aid of the Ballynahinch Methodist Church building fund.Mr Brown passed away in  with a huge number of mourners making their way to Ballynahinchrsquos Lough Inch cemetery, including leading names from the world of motorsport including Frank Williams, Patrick Head and Keith Duckworth.ldquoI will always remember Jim as a great innovative, pioneering engineer who was fired by his own initiative. He is someone the like of which we will never see again, said Alan.ldquoIrsquom sure that Ruth will know that her two brothers and I are working on an article on the le and works of her famous father which we have substantially completed and hope to feature in the Down Recorder over the coming weeks, illustrated with a number of photos taken by the paperrsquos former photographer and Ballynahinch man Jim Miskimmin.Alan also confirmed that the Brian Steenson Memorial Group is planning to have a chat show and talk about the le and work of J N Brown later this year when lockdown restrictions have eased. He also revealed that the group will also have a new cup to hand present this year called the J N Brown Memorial Cup donated by his son Junior.The Crossgar man is also appealing to anyone who may have any photos or memorabilia about Jim Brown or Mervyn McConkey to email him at alan-lyons@hotmail and has also wished Ruth every success with her new book which he thinks will be a best seller..prettyPhoto

title: Joe Toner – Ireland%2C  Arsenal and Down star
story: HE was a sporting tour de force who played football for Ireland and Arsenal. Joe Toner also played Gaelic footballer for Castlewellan and lined out on the hurling field for Down.He was born on March , . As a young man, his athleticism earmarked him as a star in the making.The GAA influence was strong one in his family. His nephew Pat Rice was a member of the Down team whichfamously brought the Sam Maguire Cup north of the border for the first time in .Reared at Bunkers Hill, he played soccer for Castlewellan Stars and neighbours Annsborough, before he went on to shine with Belfast United in the midst of World War One.Following the end of the war he came to the attention of Arsenalrsquos talent scouts and was whisked off to the famous London club in , in time for theirto the First Division following promotion.He made his debut against Everton in the newly-built Highbury stadium in October . Wearing the No  shirt, he helped his new team-mates to a - victory. He would go on to make  appearances for the Gunners.Arsenal, like so many post-war clubs, were one in ious stages of flux. The team would change regularly with players often struggling to keep their place for one reason or another.In his second season at the club, he did not feature until December.Arsenal would end the campaign ninth in the table.Despite his infrequent Arsenal appearances, international honours came along. He made his Ireland debut on April , , against Wales. The match at Windsor Park was played in front of a crowd of , and finished in a - draw. He would play eight times in all for Ireland.The arrival of the great Herbert Chapman as manager of Arsenal in  coincided with even fewer chances for Toner.He played only two games at the start of the - season and in January  he went north of the border and signed for Scottish side St Johnstone.However, he was immediately hit by injury, breaking his leg in his first full season. That injury would ultimately force him out of the club at the end of the - season after  games.The following year he ed home to Northern Ireland, going on to coach Coleraine. In fact on one occasion, owing to so many injuries in the Bannsidersrsquo team, he even made a playing appearance.A descendant of Joersquos, Peter Toner, who now lives in Cumbria in England, said Joersquos achievements were a source of great pride to his family.ldquoI had a telephone conversation with his late son Gerard [who passed away in ], who was immensely proud of his fatherrsquos footballing prowess, Peter said.ldquoHe claimed that Joe excelled in any position on the pitch. He recalled him playing for a Whitehaven side, as well as another team in a town a few miles away. That team, we later confirmed, was Cleator Moor.Remarkably, Joe is also remembered with affection at St Johnstone, even though it is almost century since he played for the Perth-based club, which plays at Muirton Park.The official St Johnstone club website still publishes a testament to his role in their history today.ldquoJoe Tonerrsquos place in St Johnstone history is assured by virtue of one simple fact: he was the first player to receive international recognition while playing for the club. He came to Perth from Woolwich Arsenal, having already been capped for his country ndash which was Ireland.ldquoA tricky, pocket-sized left winger, he had an unfortunate start to his Muirton career. He signed in January , and made his debut on the sixth of that month in a First Division match against Motherwell.ldquoSaints lost -, but the Perthshire Advertiser, displaying an unusual degree of inaccuracy noted: lsquoThe Englishman [sic], who is by no means a giant, gave indications of being a sound investment for the Saints. He made the most of any chances he got, but I do feel that he was needlessly starved in the second halfrsquo.In his relatively brief time at Muirton Park he had distinguished himself by becoming the clubrsquos first capped international player.Upon moving back to Castlewellan, his le was touched by tragedy after his we Elizabeth died in her early s from influenza. This left Joe to not only mourn her passing, but to raise their family of ten children single-handedly. He died in Castlewellan in November  at the age of .His descendant, Peter, remarked: ldquoJoe certainly had a remarkable le and left his mark, not just in his local area, but on the playing pitches of England and Scotland too.ldquoThe family are very proud of his achievements, despite the dficulties he experienced at times in his le away from sport..prettyPhoto

title: Katie living the dream on Good Morning Britain
story: SHE dreamed of being a TV weather presenter as a child and now Saintfield woman Katie Andrews has landed her dream job working in television for UTV.The  year-old is a production journalist and has been working on the stationrsquos news bulletins since .She has also become a familiar face in front of the cameras having moved into presenting for Good Morning Britain and weekend news bulletins since last November.Katie said: ldquoI had originally wanted to be a weather woman from a very young age. I always watched breakfast TV news shows before I went to school in the morning and was always attracted to TV news as I always wanted to know what was happening.She took her first step to her ideal career when she applied for the Multi-Media Journalist course at Belfast politan College.ldquoIt was my preferred choice for further education as I admired the coursersquos reputation. It provided me with opportunity to continue my higher education in Multimedia Journalism at Teesside University, where I graduated with a first class honours.Katie said her time at Belfast Met was a springboard for university.ldquoWe did a lot of group projects working in the TV and Radio studios where I had the opportunity to work on the programme Brilliant NI, so I got a real sense of what itrsquos like to self-shoot using industry standard cameras, said Katie. ldquoI also presented some segments of the programme and having this opportunity to present on Brilliant NI was when I realised that I felt comfortable presenting in front of the camera.ldquoMy favourite part of the course was the broadcasting module, as we learnt so much from our lecturers who worked in broadcasting themselves. It helped me to develop the skills I needed to work in TV and broadcasting as a whole. The course was very sociable - everyone worked together well, and we had a lot of fun along the way.After graduating from Belfast Met, Katie continued her higher education journey at Teesside University where she was named Video Journalist of the Year.This award included work experience at a local television channel in the North East of England, North East Live, where she worked as a self-shooting reporter and presenter for for two and a half years before pursuing a career closer to home with UTV.ldquoThere isnrsquot a more exciting and fulfilling job in the world. No two days are the same which I love, and I really get a buzz from working to deadlines every day, she said.ldquoMy work patterns y from producing bulletins, editing, writing and writing articles for our website. The best part of working at UTV is the teamwork thatrsquos involved, and Irsquove also really enjoyed being in front of the camera more recently as well.ldquoI get a real sense of achievement from working behind the scenes with correspondents and reporters that I have always looked up to. Itrsquos so rewarding to see the final news bulletin being broadcast following a busy day in the newsroom.ldquoI feel very lucky to be in the role I am in now, and hope I continue to have a successful career in broadcast journalism and can eventually progress into a reporting role within UTV..prettyPhoto

title: New home for Newcastle FC
story: NEWCASTLE Football Clubrsquos ambitious plans for a new home have been given a huge boost.An application by the club to relocate has been approved by planners and is expected be confirmed by Newry, Mourne, and Down Councilrsquos Planning Committee next week.The club hopes to leave its current home at Shimna College and move to Church Hill, off the Castlewellan Road, just outside the town.The exciting development involves the construction of three pitches, including a full-sized intermediate standard grass pitch. There will be two other pitches, one of which will have anarticial G surface.The club is also planning to build a clubhouse along with seating for spectators, fencing and car parking facilities, as well as a new access.Club officials are currently tight-lipped about their plans, which would represent a major boost for soccer in the Newcastle area.The clubrsquos first team has enjoyed considerable success, completing a memorable double in the - season when it won the Cochrane Corry Cup and Division B of the Amateur League.Newcastle won Division A in - and Division IB in  . The club currently plays Division A.The club also has two other teams which compete in the Newcastle League..prettyPhoto

title: Opposition to plans for grazing on beach dunes
story: PLANS to allow cattle to graze in a seafront area of special scientic interest are being opposed by two local politicians who have asked for the proposal to be put on hold.Rowallane councillor Patrick Brown and Downpatrick area councillor Cadogan Enright have voiced opposition to a joint venture by the Department for Agriculture, Environment and Rural Affairsand Newry, Mourne and Down Council to allow cattle to graze in the dune system in the Tyrella and Minerstown areas.They say residents have been made aware that in an attempt to improve the habitat of the dune system, ious steps will be taken including the removal of scrub and sea buckthorn, alongside the erection of new stock proof fencing and the installation of water drinkers for cattle and a cattle corral.The local councillors met recently with residents at one of the proposed sites and in the wake of the concerns that were expressed, have submitted a formal request for all works to be halted immediately and reconsidered to address the local communityrsquos concerns.Cllr Brown revealed that one of the key worries about the proposals is the impact it will have on the Irish Lizard and Smooth Newt, Northern Irelandrsquos only newt species which lives in the freshwater pond system and is currently getting ready to spawn.ldquoIf these plans go ahead, there will need to be sufficient protection given to ensure that grazing did not intrude on the pond system, destroying the natural habitat of these two species, he continued.ldquoAdditionally, it is argued that the buckthorn may rapidly spread, which is why it needs to be removed. However, only the female species of buckthorn exists in Northern Ireland and so concerns of this taking over are exaggerated and unfounded.Cllr Brown said the area containing the buckthorn proposed to be grazed is a natural habitat for many hedgehogs and badgers which will be disrupted and possibly displaced by the proposed grazing.He also said residents are concerned about badger baiting in the area which they fear will be made easier when sets are exposed due to the removal of natural grasses.ldquoThere are also issues around property disputes and Cllr Enright and I feel strongly that Newry, Mourne and Down Council should not be erecting fences until ownership of the property has been established, continued Cllr Brown.He added: ldquoMoreover, the money being spent on this scheme would be much better used to protect the dune-front from erosion using the same beach restoration strategies deployed in Ballyhornan. We would suggest this is a much better use of ratepayerrsquos money and urge DAERA and the council to utilise these other beach restoration strategies instead.Cllr Enright argued that grazing cattle will cause ldquosevere degradation of natural dunes which far outweighs the minimal risk from any invasive species, suggesting that the current proposals will severely impact on the coastal landscape.ldquoPermitting grazing at the seafront facing part of the dunes will only accelerate the massive loss of dunes due to unprotected footfall from thousands of people every year, as has been seen at sites such as Ballyhornan, he contended.ldquoIt is vital that Lyme, sand scutch and marram grasses that form the dunes are protected from footfall as they donrsquot regrow after the second or third time their underground growing tips are walked upon.Cllr Enright said that while there is a need to enclose parts of the dunes to combat erosion caused by human footfall and littering, he and Cllr Brown question the decision to use barbed wire given the large number of children and animals that visit the area.He added: ldquoNewry, Mourne and Down Council should provide visitors with clear messaging around what parts of the beach they can walk on,andwire has to be used, it should be sheep wire..prettyPhoto

title: Portaferry’s Ciara set to miss out on Euros
story: PORTAFERRYrsquoS Ciara Mageean has withdrawn from the Ireland team to take part in the European Indoor Athletics Championships, which begin tomorrow in Poland.In a shock announcement, Mageean said she was taking the decision after recent ldquosetbacks.The -year old has struggled in her two most recent indoor races in Germany and England.ldquoI am just not where I want to be in order to compete in the European Indoor Champs and do myself and the Irish vest justice, she said.Mageean won the bronze medal in the m at the last European Championships in Glasgow two years ago.She said she had decided to opt out of the championships following consultations with her Manchester-based coach Steve Vernon.She said she felt the decision was the right one in order to best prepare for the summer ahead. Ciara became the first Irishwoman to go under two minutes for m last summer when she improved the national record to .. in a milestone performance.She then broke Sonia OrsquoSullivanrsquos -year-old Irish m record during arguably the best performance of her career in a stellar field in Monaco. However afterwards, her form dipped in the closing three outings of her outdoor campaign.She appeared to be back on the right path back when she comfortably broke nine minutes to win a m in Manchester in early January.However, she finished a distant last in her m race at the World Indoor Tour meeting in Karlsruhe, Germany.Afterwards she said the unexpected death of her former coach, Jerry Kiernan, the previous week, had taken ldquomore from me than I anticipated.She attempted to regroup in a relatively low-key m race in Manchester a couple of weeks ago, but could only finish fourth in a time of ....prettyPhoto

title: Revitalisation fund to assist Covid recovery
story: TWO new funds are to be established to help the district recover from the devastating impact of the coronavirus.Newry, Mourne and Down Council is creating a Covid revitalisation fund to help the business community and is also establishing an economic recovery reserve as the area plots its way out of the global pandemic.The news was confirmed at the local authorityrsquos annual rates meeting on Monday night when councillors sanctioned a .% increase mdash as exclusively revealed in last weekrsquos Recorder.Designed to fund the councilrsquos pound.m budget mdash an increase of pound.m on last year ndash the above inflation rise will mean homeowners with a property valued at pound, will be paying pound. more a year or  pence a month.There was across-the-board political support for the increase at Monday nightrsquos meeting to cover the cost of delivering economic regeneration, planning services, leisure and community facilities, refuse collection and street cleansing.The increase was formally proposed by Mournes Sinn Fein councillor Willie Clarke and seconded by Rowallane DUP councillor Billy Walker.Council chairwoman Laura Devlin said setting the annual rate was one of the local authorityrsquos most important responsibilities, one that enabled the organisation to fulfil its commitments to residents and businesses.She said the past  months ldquohave been like no other with the council acutely aware of the devastating impact of COVID- and the challenges facing many of ratepayers as a result.Cllr Devlin explained that in striking the rate for the new financial year, the council has been very focused on looking towards the future of the district, mindful of the impacts of the pandemic.ldquoThe council is determined to plan for post-Covid recovery and revitalisation, she declared.ldquoWe want to proceed with the economic and regeneration plans for our district whilst ensuring we sustain the council financially over the next few years. Unlocking our tourism potential and supporting our local businesses remains a priority for me as council chair.Cllr Devlin said the council could be proud of how it responded to the public health crisis, explaining that it will continue to adapt its services as required.ldquoI have seen at first hand the efforts made to support the most vulnerable in our district over the past year and we will continue to work in partnership with other agencies to ensure we advocate for those most in need, the chairwoman added.Council chief executive Marie Ward said that when the organisation struck last yearrsquos districtrate, it had no concept of the challenges it would face over the following  months due to the global pandemic.ldquoCovid- has presented signicant financial challenges to all councils and we are no exception, said Mrs Ward. ldquoHowever, I am pleased that we have been able to sustain many services and play a key role in responding to this pandemic.ldquoAs a council we moved quickly to make our services safe and we have continued to adapt as the public health guidance has demanded.ldquoWhether it is supporting businesses through virtual workshops, helping residents stay active or connected during lockdown, working with community partners to get help to our most vulnerable residents, or carrying out environmental improvements works in our towns and villages, we have not stood still. Thank you to everyone who worked with us to make such progress possible.The chief executive said ldquoambitious thinking was required now more than ever and was pleased that progress continued to be made on major plans to regenerate the district.ldquoOver the past year, the council has progressed comprehensive outline business cases for both the Newry City Centre Regeneration and Gateway to the Mournes projects, while working with our Belfast Region City Deal partners on progressing regional programmes that will deliver digital and innovation infrastructure and an employability and skills programme, Mrs Ward continued.ldquoAhead of the council launching its new corporate plan for - in January, a new regeneration and economic development strategy was also launched, the core of which is to support local businesses and attract investment and jobs to the district.Mrs Ward said in the continuing challenging times head, none have suffered more than those who lost loved ones to Covid- or who are still recovering from this debilitating virus.She added: ldquoOur thoughts continue to be with them as well as with those facing economic hardship as result of the pandemic. I can ensure everyone of the councilrsquos commitment to press for the best possible outcomes for all our citizens as we begin to emerge from this pandemic..prettyPhoto

title: Rock Pool can boost Newcastle ‘old town’
story: NEWCASTLErsquoS historic Rock Pool should be at the heart of an ambitious revitalisation scheme for the lsquoold townrsquo area around the resortrsquos harbour.That is the view of South Down MP Chris Hazzard, who has this week called on Newry Mourne and Down Council mdash which owns the outdoor seawater pool mdash to safeguard the facilityrsquos future.Almost , people have signed a petition to preserve the iconic facility which is need of major repair work to address a number of concerning issues following a lack of major local authority investment over many years.Those behind the online petition mdash the Friends of the Rock Pool mdash want Newry, Mourne and Down Council to carry out the necessary repairs at the South Promenade facility which enjoys protected status and opened in .Campaigners insist that there is a lot of support in the community for the local authority-owned pool, with suggestions that the Heritage Lottery Fund may be one of a number of bodies which could provide a cocktail of funding to finance the much-needed repair work.As survey work continues at the pool to determine the full extent of its structural integrity and what level of investment may be required, campaigners say that the final cost of repairs to the vital community asset have not yet been confirmed.Mr Hazzard has pledged his support for the revitalisation of the historic pool and called on local council to put it at the centre of an ambitious revitalisation scheme for Newcastlersquos lsquoold townrsquo area around the harbour.ldquoThe rock pool is at the heart of what should be considered the old town in Newcastle and for a long time has played a vital role in maintaining the built heritage in this historically signicant area, he explained.ldquoThere are only two of these historically important facilitates anywhere in the North so itrsquos important that they are protected, restored and enjoyed by future generations of our local community.The MP said the local authority has already committed to the multi-million pound Mourne Gateway project though the Belfast Region City Deal, suggesting that would be sensible to integrate the Rock Pool and wider harbour area regeneration within this overall scheme.ldquoSuch an initiative would act as a catalyst to lever additional funding and interest in what could be a very exciting project to realise the huge untapped potential in Newcastlersquos old town, said Mr Hazzard.ldquoThe operating model of the rock pool should be future proofed and retained for generations to come to enjoy.Mournes councillor Willie Clarke, who represents the Newcastle area, says there is no doubt the Rock Pool needs investment.ldquoThis has been clear for many years but the local council should view this as a fantastic opportunity to invest in a unique and special facility that will also help unlock many more exciting opportunities in the local area, he suggested.ldquoHaving engaged with the local community in Newcastle for many years on the future of the Rock Pool, it is clear that Newry, Mourne and Down Council needs to explore alternative operating models that incorporates the community sector.Cllr Clarke has also suggested that such a move would perhaps allow for local activity tourism bodies and adventure water sport enthusiasts to be the driving force behind the next chapter in the Rock Poolrsquos story..prettyPhoto

title: St Patrick musical set for debut
story: A MUSICAL based on the story of St Patrick will be performed for the first time on St Patrickrsquos Day.The St Patrickrsquos Show is being broadcast from the St Patrick Centre on March .And the stars of the show will be two of Downpatrickrsquos best known performers mdash soprano Mary McCabe and musician and singer Matthew Campbell, who is a member of the acclaimed Shamrock Tenors.The -minute show is described as a ldquojourney through the ages inspired by stories and legends from Saint Patrickrsquos time right up to modern day Irish poetry.It also features features  Grammy nominated Fontaines DC frontman Grian Chatten, and other Irish artists. It is directed by Belinda Murphy, of Riverdance, Vikings and Disneyrsquos Disenchanted fame.This launch event is a precursor to a series of live events that will be held in Downpatrick thissummer, Covid restrictions permitting.These will include a live version of the Saint Patrick Show, which will incorporate a three- course dinner menu from Saint Patrickrsquos Plate, a cookery book written by award winning Irish chef Terry McCoy.The Saint Patrick Show has been funded with assistance from the Arts Council of Northern Ireland, the Community Foundation for Northern Ireland, Newry Mourne  Down Council and Fingal County Council.You can see a promotional video of the show by going to https:youtu.be iicaZh-b..prettyPhoto

title: Steven’s farm calendar raises thousands for Air Ambulance
story: AN amateur photographer from Co Down has raised a staggering pound, for the Air Ambulance Northern Ireland.Steven Evans, from Kirkistown, sold , copies of his agriculture calendar featuring imagery of farming contractors working on the Ards Peninsula.Stevensays photography and fresh air helped him through the long days after he was furloughed from his job as an automatic greaser technician during the early part of last yearrsquos pandemic lockdown.ldquoThis whole thing started out as nothing more than a comment-in-passing by one of the contractors, who spoke to me when I was out photographing their machinery working in the fields, he explained.ldquoThe thought of creating a calendar stuck in my head and, well, here we are today handing over a lot of money.ldquoThe initial idea of creating  calendars soon got out of hand and before long , copies had been printed.ldquoThe contractors featured within the calendar covered the printing costs and with all copies sold, as well as donations, handing over pound, to such a great charity is incredible.ldquoNone of this would ever have been possible without the generosity of the contractors, as well as those who bought the calendars from many local businesses who agreed to sell them on my behalf.ldquoOnly today, when doing the cheque handover, have I realised what has been achieved.Steven added: ldquoThe support has been overwhelming from the rural community, mainly on the Ards Peninsula where the calendar was photographed, showing just how much of a benefit they feel the Air Ambulance NI is.Grace Williams, Area Fundraising Manager for Air Ambulance NI, said: ldquoWe are so inspired by the creativity and generosity we are seeing from the public across Northern Ireland and the agricultural sector.ldquoSteven Evansrsquo story of creating this calendar after he had been furloughed from work is a real inspiration and we are humbled that he wanted to do this in support of Air Ambulance NI.ldquoAs a service we rely heavily on charitable donations to keep the medical team in the air, delivering critical care to patients who have suffered trauma throughout Northern Ireland mdash without this type of support, the team simply couldnrsquot fly.ldquoThe past year has been especially challenging for fundraising and wersquove seen a dramatic downturn in our income. Every single penny counts.Grace added: ldquoWe want to say a huge thank you to Steven and everyone who has supported sales of his amazing calendar..prettyPhoto

title: When Frankie Fitzsimons claimed his final winner
story: THE East Down point-to-point meeting of , which took place on March  at David Corbettrsquos estate at Tyrella, brought the curtain down for Frankie Fitzsimons.The popular Downpatrick jockey decided to call time on his long and successful career in the saddle after winning the opening race, the Alan Dunlop confined hunt race on his own horse, Killinick Robyn.Frankie always said to me that when he made the decision to retire, I would be the first reporter to know. True to his word, he informed me right away, sayingPeter Scudamore could do it, so could he.The race saw  of the  entries go to post, with Frankie making the early running. With three fences to go, the leader was Dave Anthony, ridden by John Bright, with Brian Hamilton chasing on John Turleyrsquos Friendless Friend.Anthony then crashed out and Hamilton was unseated from Fearless Friend, leaving Frankie on Killinick Robyn to win from Darragh Cross owner Judith OrsquoGradyrsquos Another Partner, ridden by James Lamb, with Raymond Martinrsquos Kasperova and Paul Parkin third.The best horses that Frankie rode over the years were Jim Gloverrsquos Hopersquos Choice, trained by his father and namesake, Frankie Sr.Frankie Sr also owned and trained young Frankiersquos first winner under rules, Bright Trick, in a Hunterrsquos Chase at Downpatrick in .One of his most notable winners was Joe Rearsquos Palo. Trained by Peter McCreery, it was the result of a big gamble the day that Frankie rode it to success at Navan.His reward that day from Joe, renowned as Downpatrickrsquos ldquobusy draper, was a new suit. I believe he still wears it on special occasions.The following week at Johnnie Grantrsquos Ramble Inn at Ballykilbeg, Frankie threw a big party for all his friends in the sport. I was lucky enough to be invited and it was a great night. Former amateur and top local funny man Terence McKeag was acting as MC. Frankie took to the stage to play the guitar and sing.Thankfully, Frankie has not been lost to the sport as he is now an officer at point-to-points, as well as being the inspector of courses. He is also a qualied steward at meetings north and south.Also at Tyrella in  there was a local winner in the two-winner race with Moving Statue, trained at Banbridge by Leo Young and ridden by Alfie Evans winning for Dromara owner David Hanna.The six-year old geldings race saw Ian Buchanan ride his own Some Day Soon to success and the Douglas and Cromie Maiden race was won by Mrs Stuart Catherwoodrsquos Bad Boy, ridden by Paddy Graffin.In the open race, Pyral, owned and trained by Moirarsquos Therese OrsquoNeill, and ridden by Graeme Martin proved to be too good for the hot favourite Mill Park Bay, ridden by Pat Kelly.At the Warwick meeting on Friday, Downpatrick jockey Caoilin Quinn recorded his first success for an outside stable when he won the racingtv Conditional Jockeys Handicap Hurdle on the   favourite Eaton Miller, trained by R Potter.Despite the fact that the race was for conditional jockeys, Caoilin was again listed on the card as a Mr. He had been a professional at this stage since early-January.This is something that does not make sense as, at present, amateur riders are unable to compete and sadly will not be able to do so at the Cheltenham Festival.They have always been a big feature of the action there, with so many Irish riders involved. Top riders like Patrick Mullins, Derek OrsquoConnor, Noel McParlan, Jamie Codd, and Barry OrsquoNeil are as effective as any professional.They are working with horses every day of the week, so it is a big disappointment for them and many others.Congratulations to Cumbria- based Downpatrick jockey Danny McMenamin on riding his th career winner. He led   shot Archie Brown at the recent Market Rasen meeting.At present, Danny leads the conditional jockeys title race on  winners. He is five ahead of Cork-born Bryan Carver. He started off in pony racing and is based with Nicky Richards, as was Anthony Dobbin..prettyPhoto

story: As a subscriber, you are shown % lessThose ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local servicesThese adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe Royal Ulster Winter Fair enters its fourth decade next week as the st Winter Fair in association with Danske Bank takes place at the Eikon Exhibition Centre, at Balmoral Park, near Lisburn.Farmers from across Northern Ireland will be travelling to the showgrounds at the Maze for the one-day event on Thursday next, December .Regarded as the premier event in the national dairy calendar, it provides an opportunity for farmers, exhibitors and industry specialists while in the showring, there will be keen competition as quality livestock from Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland compete for the coveted title of Supreme Champion.Danske Bank have sponsored the event since its inception in  and John Henning, Head of Agricultural Relations at Danske Bank commented: ldquoOur sole sponsorship of the Winter Fair now enters a fourth decade - quite an achievement in an era where such long term business relationships arenrsquot as common place, as they once were ndash and we are very proud to have sponsored one of the biggest events in the agri-food calendar in Northern Ireland during this time.We value our close links with the Winter Fair and hope that our investment in the event - both financial and people - has contributed to the undoubted success of this major dairy showcase.ldquoOur support for the Winter Fair reflects a strong and ongoing commitment to the wider agri-food industry in Northern Ireland ndash both in terms of signicant lending to the sector and expertise of our dedicated Agribusiness team.ldquoItrsquos the event lsquowhere the dairy industry meetsrsquo each December and I have no doubt that this yearrsquos Winter Fair on December  will be another outstanding success - despite dficult times in the industry and ongoing uncertainty for dairy farmers.On the cusp of Christmas, visitors flock to the Winter Fair and observe the highest quality of livestock competing. This year the RUAS are delighted to welcome Paul Trapp, who is travelling from Wisconsin, USA, to judge. The event is also a great chance to interact with  dairy related trade exhibitors on the most relevant technological advances, dficulties and solutions in the industry. Rhonda Geary, Operations Director, RUAS said: ldquo saw the move of Winter Fair to our new purpose built exhibition venue, Eikon Exhibition Centre at Balmoral Park. The move has worked brilliantly and attracted one of the largest attendances to date. In preparation for the st Winter Fair we have increased the livestock accommodation and now have stalling, washing and milking facilities for  cattle. There is m of exhibition space and a full house of  trade stands. During the Winter Fair there is a busy Seminar Suite with talks presented every half hour from am until .pm.Dr. John Bailey from AFBI will speak about better phosphorous management, Bobby Irwin of United Feeds presents a paper on getting the lactation to the right start and Roberta Simmons of the YFCU and Barclay Bell, President of the UFU will speak about succession on farms.CAFRErsquos Martin Mulholland will be advising on feed efficiency this winter, making optimum use of grass silage while Christopher Osborne form the UFU will speak about dairy commodity markets and the prospects for .Dr. Sam Strain and Sharon Verner from the Animal Health and Welfare Northern Ireland will look at improved biosecurity and BVD while Jessica Sloss from Red Tractor, speaks about the farm assurance scheme.The live calf rearing demonstration will be making afor the  Show. Gorteade Cow Care owned by Barry OrsquoLoughlin will be displaying a fully ing calf igloo with veranda and Heatwave ad lib calf feeder.One of the innovative technological features at next weekrsquos Winter Fair will be the Northern Ireland launch of the CalfApp and Calf Cloud by Volac which won gold at Eurotier in Hannover. We have been pressing the government to deal with this absurdity. This progress is good news for those impacted but there needs to be more,” she said.Mrs Foster added: “The temporary fix by the government shows they are listening, and aware of the problems being created by the Protocol, but short-term fixes are not enough. Northern Ireland needs permanent solutions, and the protocol needs to be replaced. Whilst we may be permitted to bring plants with soil attached into NI from GB, we are not actually permitted under the current lockdown to be open to sell them”.Ulster Unionist MLA Rosemary Barton welcomed the delay to a ban she described as “one of the most ludicrous outworkings” of the NI Protocol.The party’s spokeswoman on agriculture said: “Today’s news that the UK Government has acted and taken what it describes as ‘temporary, practical arrangements’... will be well received by our local horticultural industry.“Further, the permitting of the movement of plants grown in containers with soil attached from authorised businesses in GB to Northern Ireland, will enable the GB businesses to trade again and the Northern Ireland businesses to stock up for the spring.” The EU is taking legal action, accusing the UK of breaching the protocol. Ministry of Justice data shows.This was up from two over the previous three months, although it was still well below the  claims made during the same period in .More NewsCovid- cases are falling in the Vale, according to latest dataSouth Wales Police appeal to find missing teen Cameron HalesPC Tasia Stephens misconduct hearing: alleged party  crashIn the three months to December, there were also:Three property repossessionsTwo orders for tenants to leave their home by a certain dateThree warrants to evict people in breach of previous ordersIn January, the Government extended a ban on evictions ndash put in place to stop renters becoming homeless during the coronavirus pandemic ndash until the end of March.But it had previously been lted in September before being reinstated during the firebreak lockdown in late October.While landlords can still issue possession claims in court, bailfs are not allowed to evict people under the ban except in certain cases, such as for anti-social behaviour.Across Wales,  repossession claims were lodged between October and December ndash up from  the previous three months.There were  repossessions, compared to none in the three months to September, although both claims and repossessions were still well below pre-pandemic levels.Research published by the Resolution Foundation says hundreds of thousands of families across the UK have fallen into housing debt due to the impact of Covid-.ldquoThe UK is currently experiencing a mounting arrears crisis, with more than , families having fallen behind on housing payments as a result of the pandemic, said its research director Lindsay Judge.ldquoRenters have been particularly badly hit. Many have taken huge hits to their earnings and have limited savings to fall back on.ldquoTo make matters worse, measures that could ease the pressure, such as Discretionary Housing Payments from local authorities and negotiated rent reductions from landlords, are not getting through to those that need them.ldquoThis situation will worsen without signicant government intervention.The group is Homelessness Prevention Grant, both focused on tackling and preventing homelessness and providing the support people need.The spokeswoman added that the Government was looking at how to improve take-up of the Tenancy Saver Loan scheme.A UK Government spokesman said: ldquoWersquove put households right at the heart of our decision-making, spending hundreds of billions to safeguard jobs, Plus, for the first time since early December the number of people in hospital with coronavirus in Wales has fallen below ,."We have all come such a long way together," said Mr Drakeford."But we still need your help to keep one another and Wales safe. We have to keep infections as low as we possibly can."Have the rules changed From tomorrow there will be some ldquovery modest relaxations to the rules:Up to four people from two households will be are going to be treated in Wales.When will childrento school Mark Drakeford said the priority is getting the youngest children back to school, with foundation phaseing to school next week.For a safeto but evidence will accumulate to backup whichever decision is made in the next review.What is being done for older pupils with gaps in their learning due to lockdown Mr Drakeford said: "We are in very What takes many people by surprise is how strong the emotions can be, how they can change very quickly, and how long they last. People around you may seem to think you should be lsquoback to normalrsquo after a few weeks or months. You might appear to be your usual self to other people, but you know that on the inside, you are not even sure what normal is anymore.Everyone grieves in a way that is unique to them and their relationship with the person who has died. Well-intentioned people may say to you, lsquotime is a great healerrsquo. Sometimes, however, it can seem that le is more dficult as the weeks and months go by.We know that no one can understand exactly what your loss feels like to you. But we do understand that it is sometimes easier to talk to someone outside of your friends and family about grief and the impact of bereavement of your le and this is why we offer the GriefChat service.GriefChat was created by bereavement experts and by clicking on the GriefChat box below, you can chat directly to a specially trained bereavement counsellor. GriefChat counsellors are experienced in supporting bereaved people and will listen to your story, explore how your grief is affecting you and help you to find any additional support you might need. GriefChat is a completely free service and is available Monday-Friday, am-pm or by email out of these hours.GriefChat provides emotional support for bereaved people, access to trained bereavement counsellors and referral into other specialist bereavement services.Penarth Funeral DirectorsPenarth Funeral Directors aim is to provide professional care services during a time of need offering advice and support to bereaved families when they need it the most.It is our policy not to impose urgency or to apply any undue pressure on you or your family.
