story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityZak King was  when he realised he wasnrsquot going to make it as a musician, but after spending much of his childhood and teenage years growing his passion for drum and bass, he knew he needed to do whatever he could to get into the industry.The former Ysgol Gymraeg Pen-y-Garth student started his own record label that year, called Incurzion Audio, and hersquos since gone from strength to strength.With  drum and bass musicians across the UK now on board, the company became the first ever Welsh record label to make Drum and Bass Arenarsquos top  Newcomer Category in , and Mr King repeated the feat in .Explaining why he is sure Penarth is the capital of drum and bass in Wales, and possibly the UK, he said: ldquoWe believe at this stage we can say we are the biggest drum and bass record label to come out of Wales. It is judged on those awards and the quality of your signings, and wersquore proud wersquove managed to gain that title.ldquoPenarth is also home to drum and bass clothing brand Concrete Junglists which has become known worldwide, and High Contrast ndash who is a drum and bass icon ndash was born here.Talking more about how he got into the industry, Mr King said: ldquoI always wanted to be involved in the industry and realised by  I wasnrsquot going to make it as a musician.ldquoIt just wasnrsquot coming together and didnrsquot feel like it was me.ldquoItrsquos something Irsquom really passionate about but it started off as quite a light-hearted thing just giving away free music.ldquoThen it started to grow slowly and some people started to approach us, and then in  it just boomed with the top  acclaim. We started getting lots more people approach us, and wersquore now in a great position. Itrsquos been surprising.A host of top DJs including Miaszmafrom Florida, and Austrian duo Divisionand Seculahave signed up to the label, and Incurzion has grown exponentially in Florida, Austria, Germany and Russia.But strangely, Mr King says, he doesnrsquot think the label is known about by many people in Penarth.ldquoI feel wersquore starting to get rewards now for the way wersquove tried to really stand out in what is a saturated market, he said. ldquoWe feel wersquove done that by trying to offer a dferent sound and brand.ldquoOur style is deep and dark drum and bass, dark branding and graphic design ndash almost like horror.ldquoBut most of all itrsquos about bringing on board top quality musicians, and thatrsquos what wersquove managed to do.ldquoItrsquos been a massive shock to see how much interest our music is getting from Florida since Miaszma signed. Itrsquos really exciting.ldquoI donrsquot think people living in Penarth really know about this townrsquos standing in the drum and bass industry. Itrsquos quite unbelievable for a small town to have such a big connection, and I think it needs to be celebrated more.As lockdown hit last March, so did all of Incurzionrsquos events, which kept Mr King busy every week.He believes musicians have been ignored throughout the pandemic, which he worries may have caused a mental health crisis in the industry.ldquoAs live events go wersquove been absolutely decimated, he said. ldquoThe financial impact of that on venues and on companies like ours, as well as inidual musicians, has been unbelievable.ldquoBut fortunately for us our digital sales have been through the roof. That might be because people have more time on their hands at home to explore dferent genres, and itrsquos great they feel they want to purchase our music.ldquoBut the major thing for this industry is the live events, wersquore nothing without those, just like every other label and performer.ldquoThe funding has been awful, and the impact this will have on mental health seems largely ignored.ldquoThis is what we do every single week, and to have that stripped away from you for so long is dficult. title: cardiff vale launch eating disorder support website
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityTo mark Eating Disorder Awareness Week, Cardf and Vale Adult Eating Disorders Service has launched a new website to support people living with eating disorders.Created in close collaboration with service users, artists, film-makers, counsellors, psychologists, a dietitian and web designer Rhys Welsh, the new website highlights pathways people can follow to find support.Around . million people in the UK currently live with an eating disorder. Anorexia, bulimia and other eating disorders are challenging at the best of times.During the COVID- pandemic, additional stresses have included not being able to see family and friends, outdoor exercise being limited to once a day, and the potential binge-purge cycle arising from stockpiling food due to being required to shop as infrequently as possible.An eating disorder is a mental illness that manests as an unhealthy attitude to food, which can become obsessive and make you unwell.People with eating disorders might eat too much or too little, spend a lot of time worrying about body shape and weight, and have very strict routines around food and exercise. Eating disorders can affect anyone of any age, gender, ethnicity or background.Evenyour symptoms donrsquot directly match those of anorexia, bulimia or binge eating, you may still have an eating disorder. The important thing is to get help.Example of artwork that forms part of the new eating disorder websiteJo Whitfield, National Officer, Wales, at BEAT, said: ldquoThe new Cardf and Vale adult eating disorder service website is a friendly and welcoming gateway for people affected by eating disorders."Itrsquos a place where those who are contemplating seeking help for an eating disorder can find out more about the recovery journey they are about to embark on, and it provides those already undergoing treatment an inspiring place toto throughout their journey.MORE NEWS:"The content is a wonderful collaboration drawing upon lived experience from past and present users of the service. It interweaves art, photography, poetry and animation with factual advice and guidance in one accessible virtual hub, bringing reassurance, hope and belief that recovery from these serious mental illnesses is achievable and possible."The project is fantastic and I look forward to seeing the collection of art and poetry continue to grow as people continue with their journeys to recovery.The website launch is being celebrated with the opening of The Creative Insights exhibition, featuring artwork commissioned by Cardf and Vale Health Charity.Example of artwork that forms part of the new eating disorder websiteYou can view The Creative Insights exhibition via The Virtual Hearth Gallery. The healing benefits of creativity and art are central to the concept of the new website.The creation of the website provides an opportunity for service users to meet online weekly and work alongside facilitators Katja Stiller and Sarah Featherstone to relax with mindfulness, find their creative flow in writing and drawing, sharing their experiences and positive coping mechanisms.ldquoThe group formed a special bond, supporting each other through lockdown," said Debbie Woodward, Consultant Clinical Psychologist, Cardf and Vale University Health Board."Participants reported that they were grateful to have something positive to focus on in a safe space, and to give something back."One service user said the overall experience "has been truly remarkable" for them, and deem themselves lucky to have had the opportunity to take part.The website features specially created animations to help people to better understand eating disorders. The website is a collaboration between the Cardf and Vale University Health Board Psychology directorate, Dietetics, Cardf  Vale Health Charity and Tanio. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: no evidence suggest mahamud mohamed hassan tasered
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityMohamud Mohamed Hassan, , was arrested at his Cardf home on January  on suspicion of breach of the peace, but was released without charge the following day, January . Just hours later, he died suddenly.The Independent Office for Police Conducthas been investigating the incident, and has released an update, saying it is making "good progress".IOPC director for Wales, Catrin Evans, said: ldquoWe are aware that there is a lot of speculation about the circumstances surrounding Mr Hassanrsquos death and we now know that some of that is inaccurate."As a public body we have a duty, when we are able, to try to correct misinformation that may be in the public domain.The IOPC has said investigators have listened to the original emergency call from the evening of January , in which a caller claimedfive men had entered the Newport Road address and were fighting with the five occupants within the property.It said officersrsquo body worn video footage shows that on arrival a number of the occupants had injuries, and were questioned by officers at the scene about where the injuries came from.The IOPC has said it has found no evidence to suggest Mr Hassan was Tasered at any stage before or during his arrest. This followed a search of the flat, reviewing footage, officer accounts, pathology information and an audit trail of Taser use within the South Wales Police force area.The investigation continues, with IOPC still gathering accounts from "a large number" of police officers and staff who were on duty at Cardf Bay police station over two separate shts and those who were in supervisory positions.IOPC is obtaining detailed accounts from:  officers who attended the Newport Road address on January . officers who attended the Newport Road address the following evening when Mr Hassan died. officers and detention officers who were on duty over two shts at the custody suite.Plus, IOPC is gathering accounts from  officers who have been identied from events linked to the Newport Road address around that time which do not include the arrest or sudden death of Mr Hassan.Ms Evans added: ldquoThere is much more work to do to complete our investigation and our investigators continue to title: cardiff vale health board propose changes services
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityLike other regions around the UK, the Health Board faces a number of challenges, including meeting the needs of a growing and ageing population, staff shortages and outdated hospital facilities.Cardf and Vale UHB provides healthcare services and specialist services to people in Cardf and the Vale, South Wales, the whole of Wales and the wider UK.The Health Board is also a major teaching and research organisation. As one of the largest and most complex healthcare systems in the UK, it faces unique challenges in the way it develops its services, staff and ambitions for the future.Len Richards, CEO of Cardf and Vale UHB, said ldquoOur vision as a Health Board is simple a personrsquos chance of leading a healthy le should be the same no matter who they are or where they live."This is a key part of our -year Shaping Our Future Wellbeing strategy. Building on this, we would like to make a number of transformations to the way people access our clinical services, with a focus on providing more care closer to home wherever possible."Our Shaping Our Future Clinical Services programme aims to inform our communities of our thinking and seek feedback to inform our direction of travel.As part of the Shaping Our Future Clinical Services programme, the Health Board is proposing a number of changes to the way people access clinical services, including:Bringing care closer to its communities and continuing to develop Health and Wellbeing Centres and Wellbeing Hubs - as well as enhancing its model for care at home.The Health Board would like to develop Health and Wellbeing Centres in each of its three localities at Cardf Royal Infirmary, Barry and North Cardf.These will provide the infrastructure to support services that cannot be delivered through Wellbeing Hubs due to dependence on equipment, facilities or critical mass.Cardf and Vale UHB would also like to establish Wellbeing Hubs in each of its nine Primary Care Clusters, delivering services for GPs, community midwery, for children, primary mental health, community and independent living.Other proposed changes include more care happening at home or closer to home in community settings.University Hospital LlandoughUniversity Hospital of Walescould be enhanced as a centre for emergency and specialised care, focused on research and innovation, providing care for the sickest patients who have complex, specialist needs or require emergency care.The Health Board envisages University Hospital Llandoughspecialising in care for ill but stable patients who are not dependent on critical care during their stay.MORE NEWS:Routine and planned operations would take place at this site, as well as rehabilitation care and inpatient mental health services. State-of-the-art facilities would continue to be developed at UHL and a renewed UHW established.The proposed transformations to clinical services would have a number of benefits to both staff and the population. These could include:High-quality, safe and sustainable care for the future with improved outcomesAccessible care provided closer to home wherever possibleEnhanced specialist servicesState-of-the-art facilities in modern buildingsStreamlined services with shorter stays in hospital.From st March to th April , Cardf and Vale UHB is inviting members of the public to learn more about the proposed transformations and provide feedback.In partnership with the South Glamorgan Community Health Council , the Health Board will also be running a series of open public engagement events. title: dyffryn gardens joins cerys matthews backing plant health campaign
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe physical and mental health benefits of planting and growing are well understood, and as spring approaches our thoughts turn to our precious gardens, as people across Wales make their planting plans and purchases for the growing season ahead.Plant enthusiast and famous singer, songwriter, author and broadcaster Cerys Matthews is backing a Welsh Government campaign to offer advice and guidance to enhance our enjoyment of the garden, by sourcing plants carefully, inspecting them on arrival to detect and control the spread of pests and diseases, and adopting good husbandry practices.Cerys is passionate about the countryside, and created the Good Le Experience festival of culture and the great outdoors in North Wales.Cerys Matthews She said: ldquoI adore plants, I talk to them and play music to them. They are just so vitally important, providing the oxygen we breathe and the food we eat, and bring le to our iconic countryside."We need to look after plants and keep them healthy and free of plant pests and diseases.With garden centres in Wales currently closed and buyers sourcing online, the campaignrsquos key plant biosecurity messages are:Buy plants from knowledgeable suppliers who you can ask where the plant was sourced from, how to care for it, and what plant pests and diseases it might be prone to.Seek advice from Walesrsquo excellent network of independent, knowledgeable garden centres and retailers.Regularly clean your garden tools and footwear to stop the spread of invasive plants, plant pests or plant diseases.Dispose of unwanted plants and plant material responsibly. Not all plants are suitable for composting. Do not allow invasive plants, plant pests or plant diseases to spread from your land.There are a number of ways you can control plant pests, weeds and diseases. Always consider non-chemical control before using chemical pesticides.If you do decide to use pesticides, always read the product label carefully before use. This may specy or recommend specic actions for use. Always dispose of unused pesticides and pesticide containers responsibly.MORE NEWS:This Plant Health campaign is being supported by  Plant Health Sentinel Sites across Wales.These are parks and gardens, such as the National Botanic Garden, Bodnant Garden, and Dyffryn Gardens, that are working with our Animal and Plant Health inspectors to act as an early warning system for plant pests and diseases, and promoting good plant health practice to the wider public for the benefit of our wildle, the environment, our culture, well-being and economy.Dyffryn Gardens The network took part this week in a virtual event, which was addressed by Welsh Minister for Environment, Energy and Rural Affairs, Lesley Grfiths MS, a keen gardener herself.The Minister said: ldquoProtecting plants safeguards le, creating the air we breathe and most of the food we eat. We appreciate now, more than ever before, how important our plants, gardens and parks are to our le and wellbeing, and this campaign will promote best practice and help people grow healthy plants.The campaign is also backed by famous Welsh landscape designers the Rich brothers, Gold Medal winners at the RHS Cha Flower Show TV gardening presenter Meinir Gwilym and Medwyn Williams,  times Cha Gold winner for his outstanding vegetables.Further information on non-chemical control may be found on the RHS website https:www.rhs.org.uk advice profile pid.The campaign is also working with Tyfu Cymru, funded by Welsh Government to build the capacity and capability of the Welsh horticulture industry, who are spreading the biosecurity message amongst the commercial sector, raising awareness of the real threats of plant pests and diseases like Xyllela, a destructive plant pathogen best known for its effect on Italian olive trees. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. and will be opening another Cardf-based one towards the end of March.They are working in partnership with Cardf Council and Vale of Glamorgan Council to increase capacity for vaccinations and the new Bayside MVC will enable additional capacity of up to , vaccines per day, which will be dependent on vaccine supply.The new centre is being developed on the former Toys R Us site at the International Sports Village - this site will be accessible for residents in Eastern Vale and people in Cardf.Along with the mass vaccination centres, all  GP practices across the two counties are taking part in the vaccination programme, with community pharmacies set to join the programme from April.Executive Director of Public Health at Cardf and Vale University Health Board, Fiona Kinghorn, said: ldquoThis is the largest vaccination programme the NHS has even been involved in and to date tremendous progress has been made."So far we have vaccinated over a third of our adult population with first doses and some are now receiving their second doses which provides the best protection.ldquoWe are working closely with all of our partners and stakeholders to enable us to deliver the vaccine to as many people as possible as quickly as possible and have been grateful to those that have supported us through this process."Over the next few weeks we anticipate our capacity to increase in line with the new centre and support of our primary care contractors.OTHER NEWS:Volunteers helping deliver injection of hope are praised for their effortsMeet the retired haematologist and the RAF nurse helping the vaccination effortVale Cabinet Member for Health and Social Care, Cllr Ben Gray, said: "More than , vaccinations have now been given in Cardf and the Vale and the collective effort to reach this number has been nothing short of phenomenal."The Vale of Glamorgan Council has worked closely with our partners in the health board and Cardf Council to ensure we are able to administer all available vaccine as quickly as possible."This new centre for Cardf and the Vale will allow us to move through the next priority groups even more quickly and bring the end of the pandemic closer still."In addition to the new centre, the health board is also scoping out opportunities to increase local access in the Western Vale of Glamorgan. story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityKatersquos comments are part of a BBC programme featuring the royal family celebrating the Commonwealth which will be screened on Sunday, a few hours before the Duke and Duchess of Sussexrsquos bombshell interview with Oprah Winfrey.The growing war of words from Meghan and Harryrsquos controversial televised chat have overshadowed the special programme marking Commonwealth Day.In extracts released over the last few days, Meghan has criticised the constraints she faced as a working royal, and said it was ldquoliberating to be able to ldquosay yes to a request for an interview with the US chat show host.She accused The Firm ndash as the royal family is sometimes known ndash of ldquoperpetuating hoods about her and Harry.The wider royal family ndash including the Queen, the Prince of Wales, the Duchess of Cornwall and the Countess of Wessex ndash will appear in the BBC show called A Celebration For Commonwealth Day.In an extract from the programme, Kate and William chat in a video call with Dr Zolelwa Sumba, from South Africa, an advocate for the rights of healthcare workers on the front line.The duchess tells the medic: ldquoHere in the UK therersquos been masses of public recognition of the amazing work the front line are doing and itrsquos sad, almost, that itrsquos taken the pandemic for the public to really back and support all those working on the front line.This Sunday, March th  is a big day for me and all the health care workers I fight for GLOBALLY.. I feature in an interview with the royals on my Advocacy.pm.. Tune in.. Invite your friends and your friends friends.. See me represent health care workers on a global stage## pic AkygzjVgIkmdash Dr Zolelwa SumbaMarch , William, Kate and their children were pictured last year joining in the weekly applause for frontline workers during the early part of the pandemic.Dr Sumba replies: ldquoWe actually know the problems, we see the problems every day, you walk into work there are the problems.ldquoThe problem is our voices are not heard. We are on the front lines and we are expected to lt humanity. So my advice to everybody is,you know a healthcare worker ndash any healthcare worker ndash you just love on them, love on them, love on them some more.ldquoIf their child needs looking after offer, you know,they need a meal, offer.William says: ldquoWe, Catherine and I, have spoken to a lot of healthcare workers in UK and around the world over the last year ndash we hear your worries and your concerns and thank you for your time chatting to us about it.It was at Westminster Abbeyrsquos Commonwealth Day service in March last year when the Sussexes were last seen with their family, sitting close to the Queen, Charles, Camilla and William and Kate.A few months before that they had sent shockwaves through the monarchy by announcing they would be stepping down as working royals.During the programme, Charles pays tribute to the ldquoextraordinary determination, courage and creativity of the Commonwealthrsquos people during the Covid crisis.Speaking from Westminster Abbey, where he was last seen publicly with Meghan and Harry, he says the pandemic and climate change are ldquoexistential threats which have no borders. vw,vw,px, px"Charles giving his speech during the Commonwealth programme The prince says: ldquoThe coronavirus pandemic has affected every country of the Commonwealth, cruelly robbing countless people of their lives and livelihoods, disrupting our societies and denying us the human connections which we so dearly cherish.ldquoAmidst such heart-breaking suffering, however, the extraordinary determination, courage and creativity with which people have responded has been an inspiration to us all.ldquoThis pandemic has shown us the true nature of a global emergency. We have learned that human health, economic health and planetary health are fundamentally interconnected and that pandemics, climate change and bioersity loss are existential threats which know no borders.Camilla is featured speaking to broadcaster Clare Balding about how her interest in books was inspired by her father Major Bruce Shandrsquos love for literature. vw,vw,px, px"Camilla speaks to Clare Balding The duchess says: ldquoIrsquove always had a passion for books. Books have been part of my le for so long. I started reading when I was very very young with a father who has a fervent bibliophile.ldquoSo from the age of two or three he used to sit and read to us children, take us on wonderful adventureshellip all over the world.The piece was recorded at Westminster Abbeyrsquos Poetsrsquo Corner and the pair were joined by videolink by award-winning teacher Ranjitsinh Disale.Camilla says: ldquoI think I was bitten at that age and from then Irsquove just kept going, and Irsquove got involved in a lot of literacy programmes and patronages. I just feel very strongly that all children should be taught to read. vw,vw,px, px"The Countess of Wessex is also featured during the programme Sophie marked Commonwealth Day and International Womenrsquos Day, which are both celebrated on Monday, by speaking by videolink to three women from around the Commonwealth, to hear about their experiences of supporting other women and their wider communities..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Kate highlights public support for  uamazing u work of frontline staff article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: have your say on management of forest parks
story: Police appeal for information after attack caught on video   Removal of interface barrier in NI town is welcomedNewsTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthPeopleRead ThisCoronavirusSportFootballOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoHomes and GardensLestyleCarsHomes and GardensPublic NoticesAdvertise My BusinessNewsHave your say on management of forest parksAgriculture Minister Gordon Lyons is asking the public to take part in a public consultation about the management of forests in County Armagh.By The NewsroomFriday, th March , : am  "       "  "Gosford Forest Park in Co Armagh is part of the consultationThis consultation is part of a programme of reviewing all plans for Forest Service managed forests and woodlands across Northern Ireland.Mr Lyons said: “Forests are a vital natural resource which belong to us all. As our forests develop as places of industry, environment and leisure, we are encouraging everyone to make their views known.“County Armagh boasts some of Northern Ireland’s best known, and most popular, forests such as Gosford and Slieve Gullion forests. Both of these forest parks have had considerable investments in recent years by the local Councils in partnership with Forest Service, to improve and develop paths, trails and playparks.”Forests in County Armagh are also working forests that produce timber for the Northern Ireland wood processing industry. From County Armagh each year Forest Service supplies around , lorry loads of timber every year. Forest Service has also planted around , trees in the county in the last five years.The Minister continued: “Reviewing forest plans ensures that they are up to date and allows us to continue to meet the erse and sometimes competing needs of people, wildle and wood processing industries. We want to hear from all stakeholders to ensure that all interests are considered, including from those who live and work in local rural communities.”The consultation opened on  March and ends on  April . title: ryanair to return to belfast city with  new routes for summer
story: Ryanair has announced it willto Belfast City Airport after  years and is delighted to launch  new routes for summer ’ connecting Belfast to a host of popular international summer destinations. NI consumers can now book a sunshine getaway to summer favourites including Malaga , Mallorca , Faro , Alicante , Barcelona , Ibiza , Milan Bergamoand Valencia , flying on the lowest fares and with the option to avail of Ryanair’s “zero change fee” offer should plans change. To celebrate theto Belfast City Airport, Ryanair has launched a seat sale, with fares available from just pound. for travel from June to October , which must be booked by midnight Saturday, thMarch only on Ryanair. Ryanair’s Director of Marketing, Dara Brady said: “We are delighted to make ato Belfast City Airport this summer, having previously operated here in . The UK Govt’s highly successful rollout of their vaccination programme gives customers the confidence that travel will be possible this summer and NI consumers now have  routes at low fares to some of the most popular summer holiday destinations in Spain, Portugal and Italy to choose from. To celebrate the launch of these  summer routes from Belfast City, we are launching a seat sale with fares available from just pound.for travel from June to October , which must be booked by midnight Saturday, thMarch only on Ryanair.We look forward to welcoming NI customers on board our flights to the likes of Alicante, Barcelona, Milan and Valencia this summer. A much-deserved getaway is only a click away, so to avoid disappointment, we advise customers to act fast and book before these amazing low fares are snapped up.” CEO of Belfast City Airport, Brian Ambrose said: “This is excellent news for those in Northern Ireland considering a getaway this summer. The choice of routes offered by Ryanair will facilitate both city breaks and relaxing beach holidays for our passengers. Travel has been signicantly restricted over the last  months and as the vaccine rollout continues at pace and the restrictions ease, we expect there will be considerable demand for these routes, and
